Preparation of amorphous copper - chromium oxides catalysts for selective oxidation of cyclohexane Lei Sun a Junhua Liu a ⁎ Wei Luo a Yue Yang a Fang Wang b Chandima Weerakkody c Steven L. Suib c a College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, 210023, China College of Chemistry and Materials Science Nanjing Normal University Nanjing 210023 China b College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, 211816, China College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 China c Department of Chemistry, University of Connecticut, Storrs, Connecticut 06269, USA Department of Chemistry University of Connecticut Storrs Connecticut 06269 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The results show that high activity of CuCrOx depends on the presence of tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions, which play the synergistic catalytic role with chromium. After calcination, the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions were transformed into octahedrally coordinated ones, resulting in a negative effect on the catalytic activity. Meanwhile, a difference of selectivity of KA-oil existed over CuCrOx catalysts before and after calcination. Oxidation of cyclohexane is more inclined to produce cyclohexanol before calcination due to the presence of the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions, and the appearance of surface lattice oxygen makes the reaction more conducive towards cyclohexanone after calcination. In this work, amorphous copper-chromium catalysts with different Cu/Cr molar ratios have been prepared by a sol-gel method and were used in the oxidation of cyclohexane to KA-oil. The catalysts have been characterized by a variety of analytical techniques including XRD, XPS, Raman, FT-IR, BET, TEM and SEM. XRD results confirmed that the formation of amorphous structure. The XPS and Raman results indicated that most of Cu species existed in well-dispersed tetrahedral coordination before calcination. After calcination, the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions are transformed into octahedral coordination and the activity of catalyst is significantly reduced. The results show that the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions play the synergistic catalytic role with Cr ions. Interestingly, oxidation of cyclohexane is more inclined to produce cyclohexanol with uncalcined catalyst due to the presence of the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions; however, the appearance of surface lattice oxygen makes the reaction more conducive to cyclohexanone after calcination. After optimizing conditions, Cu-Cr oxide catalyst with the molar ratio 1:1 shows the highest activity, which obtains 62.2% yield and 92.4% selectivity for KA-oil using H2O2 as oxygen source. Keywords Amorphous copper-chromium oxides Tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions Selective oxidation of cyclohexane 1 Introduction It is commonly known that direct functionalization of saturated sp3 CH bond is a major challenging in chemical reaction engineering [1,2]. Cyclohexane is a vital saturated hydrocarbon, whose oxidation products are mainly cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone (a mixture called KA-oil). They are important chemical raw materials for the synthesis of caprolactam, adipic acid and other fine chemicals such as pharmaceutical coating dyes. Caprolactam and adipic acids are the raw materials for synthetic fibers nylon 6 and nylon 66 [3,4]. In industry, oxidation of cyclohexane mainly uses cobalt salt and boric acid as the homogeneous catalysts under 413–453 K and 0.81–1.22 MPa and produces KA-oil with 75–80% selectivity, limiting the conversion to 3–4% [5]. Obviously, severe pollution, low conversion and higher energy consumption are becoming increasingly serious. It is necessary to raise the KA-oil yield under mild conditions. Heterogeneous catalysts are widely applied in chemical industry because of simple separate features [6]. Lots of researchers have been devoted to heterogeneous catalysts instead of conventional homogeneous catalysts, including precious metals such as Au [7,8], transition metal oxides [9,10], molecular sieves [11], phosphates [12,13] and heterogeneous metal complexes [14,15]. Various sources of oxidants have been explored such as oxygen [16], hydrogen peroxide [12,15] and alkylhydroperoxide [17,18]. However, in view of its unstable chemical nature, TBHP is inconvenient to transport and has potential safety hazards [19]. Meanwhile, compared with hydrogen peroxide, the activity of molecular oxygen is not high, which hardly forms highly reactive oxygen radicals [20]. Therefore, as an efficient, clean and green oxidant, hydrogen peroxide has become a hot research topic in recent years, especially in the field of CH bond oxidation [21]. Compared with crystalline catalysts, amorphous catalysts have their own unique superiority, for example, highly surface area and dispersed active ingredients [22,23]. They are very interesting and worth exploring for catalysis. In fact, some catalytic reactions, such as aldol condensation [24], hydrogen generation [25], oxidation [26,27] and alkylation [28] have been reported. For example, Gedanken reported amorphous transition metal iron oxide loaded TiO2 catalyzed cyclohexane oxidation at 70 °C, which gave 21.3% cyclohexane conversion [23]. Herein, we have synthesized high specific surface amorphous copper-chromium mixed oxides by propylene oxide aided sol-gel method, whose catalytic activity was explored in selective oxidation of cyclohexane. The cyclohexane conversion and KA-oil selectivity were obtained as 67.3% and 92.4% respectively, using H2O2 as the oxygen source at 65 °C. The characterization and experimental results show that the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions are associated with the activity of the catalyst. Moreover, oxidation of cyclohexane is more inclined to produce cyclohexanol with uncalcined catalyst due to the presence of the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions; however, the appearance of surface lattice oxygen makes the reaction more conducive to cyclohexanone after calcination. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were analytic grade without any purification. Copper-chromium amorphous catalysts have been prepared by a sol-gel method using propylene oxide [28]. Cu (NO3)2·3H2O and CrCl3·6H2O were used as the reaction precursor. The reagents were added maintaining the mole ratio of Cu : Cr = 1:2, 1:1 and 2:1, respectively. Cu (NO3) 2·3H2O and CrCl3·6H2O were added into 25 ml of absolute ethanol. The solution was sonicated at room temperature for 0.5 h. To this solution, 10.5 ml propylene oxide was added dropwise with stirring. A dark green xerogel was formed after 20 min of ultrasound exposure. Then the xerogel was washed five times by ethanol, dried at 80 °C in vacuum and calcinated at 650 °C for 6 h. The catalysts were labeled as CuxCr1-xOs before calcination (where x represents the Cu/(Cr + Cu) atomic mole ratio), and CuxCr1-xOs(cal) after calcination. CrOs and CuOs were synthesized by the same procedure. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a Rigaku/Max-3 A X-ray diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). Diffraction patterns in the 5°-90° 2θ range were collected at a rate of 0.5 degrees per minute. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB250XI X-Ray photoelectron spectrometer and the binding energies ( ± 0.1 eV) were determined with respect to the position of C 1 s peak at 284.56 eV. The FT-IR spectra were recorded using Bruker Tensor 27 Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer employing KBr disks. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a FEI Quanta 200 F, using tungsten filament doped with lanthanumhexaboride (LaB6) as an X-ray source, fitted with an ETD detector with high vacuum mode using secondary electrons and an acceleration tension of 10 or 30 kV. Samples were analyzed by spreading them on a carbon tape. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded using a JEOL JEM 2100 microscope, and samples were prepared by mounting an ethanol-dispersed sample on a lacey carbon Formvar coated Cu grid. The Raman spectrum was collected using a Labram HR 800 microspectrometer (Jobin Yvon) with a 785 nm laser excitation source at 100 mW. The surface area (BET) was measured using ASAP2020 by nitrogen adsorption at 77 K. Prior to measurements, the sample was pretreated at 353 K for 3 h under vacuum. 2.3 Catalytic oxidation In a typical reaction, liquid-phase oxidation of cyclohexane was carried out in a neck round bottom flask equipped with a condenser. Successively, 0.05 g catalyst, 10 ml solvent, 0.5 ml cyclohexane and H2O2 (30% solution) were added into the flask. The reaction was carried out under continuous stirring for the required time and temperature. After reaction, the products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC 9560) connected with a SE-54 capillary column. The identification of product was carried out by injecting the standard samples into GC. The catalyst was recovered via centrifugation, washed thoroughly with ethanol and reused for multiple circles. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD measurements As shown in (Fig. 1 a, b, c), the samples are found to be amorphous before calcination. The characteristic peaks of Cu2CrOs are attributed to the Cu2(OH)3NO3 (JCPDS: 75–1779). Due to the weak peak intensity, most of the metal is still in an amorphous structure (Fig. 1d). In addition, CuOs is also attributed to the Cu2(OH)3NO3 (JCPDS: 75–1779), whose crystallinity is obviously better than Cu2CrOs, due to more characteristic peaks at 2θ = 25.7°, 33.6° and 36.5°(Fig. 1e). On the curve of CuCr2Os and CuCrOs, some weak diffraction peaks appear at lower angles, suggesting a small amount of copper species exists in these samples. As can be seen from (Fig. 1f–i), the amorphous materials are transformed to the CuCr2O4 spinel (JCPDS: 88-0110) and metal oxide after calcination. The Cu2+ undergoes thermodynamic competition, resulting in more stable metal oxide during high temperature heating [30]. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 18.8°, 29.6°, 31.1°, 35.2°, 37.7° and 42.4° are attributed to the tetragonal structure of CuCr2O4 spinel (JCPDS: 88-0110). The diffraction peaks (Fig. 1g) at 2θ = 24.5°, 33.5°, 36.2°, 41.5°, 50.3° and 54.9° are attributed to Cr2O3 phase (JCPDS: 85-0703). Additionally, diffraction peaks at 2θ = 32.4°, 38.7°, 48.7°, 66.3°, 72.3° and 75.2° are assigned to CuO phase (JCPDS: 45-0937) and the peak intensity of CuO phase increases gradually with the raising Cu ratio (Fig.1h–i). CrOs (cal) exists in the form of pure Cr2O3 (Fig. 1f, JCPDS: 85-0703). The average crystallite sizes of the catalyst are determined by the half-width at 2θ = 35.2° peak using the well-known Scherrer equation (Table 1 ) [29,31]. 3.1.2 Morphologies and structures of catalysts The morphology, particle size and crystallinity of the various samples are examined by TEM. The CuCrOs and CrOs display irregular appearance and the approximate size is above 100 nm (Fig. 2 a, c), there are no obvious lattice diffraction fringes for them (Fig. 2b, d). Therefore, it can be described as an amorphous structure, which is consistent with XRD data. After calcination, the particles of CuxCr1-xOs (cal) are mostly spherical or ellipsoidal in shape and the approximate size of the particles varies from about 40–60 nm (Fig. 2e, m, g, i). In addition, the lattice fringes in CuxCr1-xOx(cal) with a lattice spacing of 0.50 nm and 0.27 nm are attributed to the [101] and [211] planes of the spinel CuCr2O4 (Fig. 2f, h, k), which indicated Cu2+ ions can be transferred to Cr2O3 lattice to form a unique spinel structure [32,33]. Moreover, the lattice spacing shown in the image (i, l) were approximately 0.23 nm and 0.25 nm, representing the [111] and [-111] planes of CuO phase [34], so there exists a certain amount of CuO in the CuCrOs (cal) and Cu2CrOs (cal). The lattice spacing of 0.27 nm is identified as Cr2O3 (Fig. 2n) [35]. SEM images of as-prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . It can be clearly seen that the size and morphology of the particles have undergone significant changes for the CuxCr1-xOs catalysts before and after calcination; the stacked single-layer sheet structure (Fig. 3a–d) transforms into a regular geometric appearance (Fig. 3e–h). This is also an important reason why the specific surface and pore size distributions of the catalysts are reduced obviously. However, the grain size is non-uniform due to the presence of CuO phase (Fig. 3f, g), and the homogeneity of particles is mainly attributed to the formation of pure spinel and chromium oxide, respectively (Fig. 3e, h). 3.1.3 FT-IR studies FT-IR spectra of the Cu-Cr oxides catalysts are analyzed, and they not only confirm the change of chemical bond, but also reveal the interaction between the two metals. IR spectra (Fig. 4 a–d) show strong and broad absorption peak at 3300-3400 cm−1, medium and sharp peak at 1618 cm−1 due to the presence of hydroxyl and adsorbed water molecules, respectively [36]. The hydroxyl can be confirmed to coordinate at the Cr3+ sites [37]. The peaks at 1383 and 1351 cm−1 can be attributed to the vibration modes of NO3- [38] and the peak at 1046 cm-1 is ascribed to the deformation vibration of CO bond [39]. The vibration at 508 cm−1 is attributed to the Cr-O [40]. In addition, the weak peak appearing at 429 cm−1 is considered as the stretching vibration of the Cu-N coordination bond [41]. Adsorption peaks of water and hydroxyl decreased significantly after calcination (Fig. 4e, g, h). The bands at 609 cm−1 and 520 cm−1 are ascribed to bending vibration modes of Cr-O and Cu-O, corresponding to octahedral and tetrahedral sites of spinel. Appearance of these feature bands indicates the formation of spinel structures [42]. Meanwhile, the peaks at 581 and 639 cm−1, both of which represent vibrational modes of pure Cr2O3, are attributed to Cr-O-Cr or O-Cr-O vibrations in CrOs (cal) [43,44]. Compared with CuCrOs (cal) and Cu2CrOs (cal), the peak at 520 cm-1 (Cu-O bond) of CuCr2Os (cal) is more sharp, which means that there are more tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions in the CuCr2Os (cal). 3.1.4 Raman spectra Complementary to the infrared spectrum, Raman spectra can be used to confirm the formation of the Cu-Cr oxides as shown in Fig. 5 . For all the Cu-Cr oxides catalysts before and after calcination, it is obvious that Raman spectra of the samples are rather similar, and all the bands are relatively broad [45]. Especially, a strong peak at 702 cm−1 is related to A1g mode that reflects the vibration of tetrahedrally coordinated metal with oxygen [30,46]. The bands at 250, 464, 539, 581, and 617 cm−1 basically are attributed to the vibrational modes of the octahedral sublattices [30,45]. 3.1.5 Surface property investigations 3.1.5.1 Cu XPS The valences and site distributions of Cu in Cu-Cr oxides catalysts are characterized by XPS surface analysis (Fig. 6 ). All spectra are characterized by two main peaks of Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 [47,48]. The low energy peaks of Cu 2p3/2 at 933.0–934.2 eV are generally attributed to Cu2+ in octahedral sites, while the high energy peaks at 935.1–935.6 eV correlate with Cu2 + at the tetrahedral sites [31]. The peaks at 932.1–932.4 eV can be attributed to the states of Cu+ [49]. The typical satellite lines of Cu2+ ion, about 8.5 eV from the main peak, indicates the 3d ∼ 4 s shake-up transitions [50]. The peaks at 941.3 eV and 943.7 eV correspond to the shake-up satellite lines, which attributed to Cu2+ ions. However, there are no corresponding satellite lines for Cu+ species, as the shake-up transitions do not occur in filled 3d shells [51]. Before calcination, majority of the Cu2+ ions occupy tetrahedral sites, and only a small amount of them are located in octahedral sites. Nevertheless, the peak intensities of tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions decrease and the peak intensities of octahedral copper ions increase due to the increase in octahedrally coordinated Cu ions after calcination, as the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions move to the octahedral position. According to previous reports, CuO was attributed to octahedral coordination copper in copper-chromium composite oxides [31]. The results show that octahedrally coordinated Cu ions are assigned to the surface CuO phase and the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions enter spinel structure, which is consistent with conclusion from XRD. Meanwhile, an increase of the content of Cu+ ions is attributed to the reduction of the Cu2+ ions by a reducing gas, which was caused by the decomposition of organic substances during the calcination process [29]. 3.1.5.2 Cr XPS The XPS of Cr 2p3/2 for the Cu-Cr oxides catalysts is shown in Fig. 7 . Cr 2p3/2 showed two main peaks at 576.1–577.0 eV and 578.2–578.6 eV, which are typical for the binding energies of Cr3+ and Cr6+ [31,42]. Obviously, the chromium ions are mainly in the trivalent states. The Cr 2p3/2 of CuxCr1-xOs catalysts (576.1 eV–577.0 eV) is lower than that of CrOs (576.6 eV–577.0 eV), so there is a negative shift after forming the composite oxide, and this indicates the existence of a strong interaction between the Cu-O-Cr and Cr-O-Cr bonds. In addition, the peak at approximately 575.3 eV indicates a non-stoichiometric oxide phase between the metallic chromium and Cr2O3 [43]. 3.1.5.3 O XPS The XPS spectra of O 1 s in Cu-Cr oxides catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . The curve of O 1 s is split into three peaks at about at 529.6–530.1, 531.2–531.9, and 532.6–533.5 eV, which can be attributed to lattice oxygen (O2−, denoted as Olatt), surface hydroxyl groups, and CO or adsorbed water, respectively [52–54]. Before calcination, catalysts contain a numbers of surface hydroxyl groups, which is consistent with FIIR characterization. After calcination, the levels of oxygen species on the surface of the catalyst have changed significantly. It is found the decreased concentration of surface hydroxyl groups and increased concentration of lattice oxygen that plays an important role in activation of CH bond [55]. In contrast to the peak of lattice oxygen (O2−) of CrOs (cal), the peaks of CuCr2Os (cal), CuCrOs (cal) and Cu2CrOs (cal) were slightly shifted to lower binding energies, suggesting less interaction between lattice oxygen and Cu. This could be attributed to the exposure of CuO on the surface [55]. 3.2 Activity of the catalyst Table 3 shows the activities of the different stoichiometry ratio Cu-Cr oxides catalysts for the oxidation of cyclohexane using H2O2 as an oxidant. Notably, conversion of cyclohexane was significant decreased and KA-oil selectivity keep high level after calcination. However, the selectivity for cyclohexanone has been obviously improved. A blank experiment was conducted in absence of catalyst, and the conversion of cyclohexane was too poor to be detected. Through the reaction data, CuCr2Os, CuCrOs and Cu2CrOs achieved higher conversions in the cyclohexane oxidation reaction, corresponding to 48.0%, 67.3% and 53.2%, respectively. It is interesting that the conversions are gradually increasing with the increase of Cu/Cr mole ratio. As the related values of Cu t 2+/Cu2+ tol are corresponding to 0.88, 0.95, and 0.94, respectively, it can be concluded the higher proportion of tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions is associated with the activity of the catalyst due to their coordinative unsaturation before calcination. After calcination, CuCr2Os (cal), CuCrOs (cal) and Cu2CrOs (cal) only obtained 25.9%, 3.2%, 1.5% conversion of cyclohexane, respectively. Obviously, the catalytic activity of CuxCr1-xOs is greatly reduced after calcination (Table 3). To explore this significant reduction in catalytic activity, the experiments were performed over pure CrOs and CuOs compound. CrOs (cal) itself could obtain 39.4% conversion of cyclohexane (entry 9), which increased beyond 11.4% than that before calcination. But the CuOs (cal) had almost no catalytic activity (entry 10). The results show that Cr plays a more important role in catalytic activity and octahedrally coordinated Cu ions had no any catalytic activity. Therefore, for the CuxCr1-xOs catalysts, the decrease in catalytic activity is closely related to reduce of tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions except the reduction of the specific surface (Table 1). As the XPS data confirmed that CuxCr1-xOs catalysts have a higher content of octahedral coordination copper ions after calcination. Obviously, it is unfavorable for this reaction when tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions are transformed into octahedral coordination. Although the proportion of chromium of CuCrOs (cal) is higher compared with Cu2CrOs (cal), both of them have almost no catalytic activity (entry 7, 8). Similarly, the proportion of chromium of CuCr2Os (cal) is higher than that of CuCrOs (cal), but CuCr2Os (cal) still retains 25.9% conversion of cyclohexane (entry 6). XPS show Cu t 2+/Cu2+ tol value of CuCrOs (cal) (0.23) is very close to that of Cu2CrOs (cal) (0.19), however, the corresponding Cu t 2+/Cu2+ tol value of CuCr2Os (cal) (0.55) is more than twice as that of CuCrOs (cal) (0.23). Obviously, these indicate that tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions play an inhibitory role in reducing catalyst activity. As a supplement to XPS, FT-IR characterization also shows more tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions in the CuCr2Os (cal). Therefore, we conclude that tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions promote the activity of chromium ones. So we believe that synergistic catalysis between the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu and Cr ions plays a vital role in the oxidation of cyclohexane. Furthermore, there is an obvious difference in selectivity for cyclohexanol or cyclohexanone before and after calcination, and this may be due to the different reaction routes. When more tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions exist in the CuCr2Os (0.88), CuCrOs (0.95) and Cu2CrOs (0.94), the ratio of alcohol/ketone gradually increased to 1.1, 1.4 and 2.0. Therefore, it can be concluded that tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions have the higher tendency towards the formation of cyclohexanol. After calcination, the lattice oxygen species of CuxCr1-xOs and CrOs exceed 50% and 60% (Tables 2 and 3 ), respectively, which have strong nucleophilicity and play a key role in selective oxidation. On the basis of data from CrOs (cal) and CuCr2Os (cal), the selectivity of cyclohexanone is almost twice than that of cyclohexanol (entry 6, 9). Thus, the surface lattice oxygens attributed to terminal chromyl species (Cr-Olatt) could be more favorable for the formation of cyclohexanone. The relevant mechanism will be further discussed in Schemes 1 and 2 . 3.3 Effect of reaction parameters The influence of various parameters, such as temperature, ratio of substrate-to-oxidant, reaction time, catalyst weight and solvent, on the oxidation of cyclohexane over CuCrOs was investigated and shown in Tables 4–7 . Catalytic activity is significantly different in various polar solvents (Table 4), and only acetonitrile gives the best result. This may be due to its relatively good solubility for cyclohexane as well as aqueous H2O2, and acetonitrile could react with H2O2 to form an active intermediate for the transfer of active oxygen, thus acetonitrile exhibits the best performance for selective oxidation of cyclohexane [12]. With increasing temperature, the conversion of cyclohexane increases rapidly. However, beyond 65 °C, the conversion starts to decline because the increasing temperature accelerates the decomposition of H2O2 (Table 5). The results indicate that the increasing molar ratio of H2O2: cyclohexane generates a rapid increase in the conversion, but simultaneously, it does not affect on KA-oil selectivity (Table 6). The optimal yield of 62.2% was obtained when the molar ratio was increased to 1:4. Continuously, a slight decline occurs for the conversion of cyclohexane (33.2%) when the amount of H2O2 further increases and this may be due to the competitive adsorption relationship between alkylperoxy species and H2O2 on active sites. The influence of catalyst amount on the catalytic activity was investigated at 65 °C for 4 h (Table 7). Weight of catalyst in the range of 0.025-0.05 g facilitates the conversion of cyclohexane. Beyond this range, the conversion of cyclohexane decreased, perhaps the increase of active sites accelerates the decomposition of H2O2 to generate oxygen. Recycled catalyst can be used up to 5 times and no obvious loss of activity was detected under our conditions. Moreover, when the catalyst was filtered off, further treatment of the filtrate under similar reaction conditions did not afford to any products. 4 Mechanistic consideration Scheme 1 depicts a possible reaction path over the CuxCr1-xOs. It is reported that the oxidation of cyclohexane follows the mechanism of free radicals [56]. A free radical scavenger is used in this oxidation reaction to verify the viewpoint. First, cyclohexane (CyH) is activated by H2O2 to give cyclohexyl radical (Cy ) [12], which was then captured by molecular oxygen to form cyclohexylperoxy radical (CyOO ). Afterward, CyOO can extract H from H2O2 to form intermediate cyclohexyl hydroperoxide (CyOOH) (Step 1) [56]. This process is considered as a preactivation stage. It is generally believed that the Haber-Weiss mechanism plays a vital role in decomposing of ROOH to form RO and peroxyalkaneoxy radicals (ROO ) [57]. In Cu-Cr oxides catalysts, CyOOH can form an unstable transitional state with tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions, whose dissociation products are CyOO and CyO (Step 2, 4). Decomposition of ROOH to give ROO , through Cu sites is a very unfavorable process (Step 4). This would lead to form an excess of alcohol with respect to the ketone with the catalyst before calcination. Accordingly, the CyO remains adsorbed to the Cu center. Afterwards, in the presence of a proximal CyH, a H-abstraction reaction occurs, with the formation of Cy and cyclohexanol (CyOH) (Step 3). In the same time, according to Russell termination mechanism, two molecules CyOO further produce the ultimate product CyOH, cyclohexanone (CyO) and O2 (Step 5) [58]. Scheme 2 depicts the possible reaction path way over the CuCr2Os (cal) catalyst. The activated Cy interacts with Crδ + on the surface of the catalyst by a chelation behavior, so that the free radical is anchored long enough for the next reaction [12]. Being nucleophilic species, the surface lattice oxygen attacks the electron-deficient site of the hydrocarbon molecule through addition reaction [59]. Consequencely, it may form oxygen-chromium-carbon cyclic species, which undergoes charge transformation to form the cyclohexanone as the main product. 5 Conclusions We have prepared Cu-Cr amorphous oxides catalysts with high surface area by a propylene oxide aided sol-gel method. By optimizing reaction conditions, we find the CuCrOx catalyst can efficiently catalyze the oxidation of cyclohexane; 62.2% yield and 92.4% selectivity for KA-oil is obtained using H2O2 as the oxygen source. (1) The results show that high activity of CuCrOx depends on the presence of more tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions. After calcination, the reduction of the surface area is an important reason for the decreased catalytic. However, the deep-rooted reason is that the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions are transformed into octahedrally coordinated Cu ions, resulting a negative effect on the catalytic activity. The CuCr2Os (cal) with a higher percentage of a Cu2+/Cu2+ tol still retains highly active compared to the CuCrOs (cal) and Cu2CrOs (cal), indicating tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions are favorable for this reaction. (2) It exhibits a difference in selectivity for KA-oil with the catalyst before and after calcination. Before calcination, oxidation of cyclohexane is more inclined to produce cyclohexanol due to the presence of the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions; however, the appearance of the surface lattice oxygen makes the reaction more conducive towards cyclohexanone after calcination. (3) The proposed method provides a potential strategy for the related research because of its low cost, simple operation and environmental friendliness. coredata.dc:description: In this work, amorphous copper-chromium catalysts with different Cu/Cr molar ratios have been prepared by a sol-gel method and were used in the oxidation of cyclohexane to KA-oil. The catalysts have been characterized by a variety of analytical techniques including XRD, XPS, Raman, FT-IR, BET, TEM and SEM. XRD results confirmed that the formation of amorphous structure. The XPS and Raman results indicated that most of Cu species existed in well-dispersed tetrahedral coordination before calcination. After calcination, the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions are transformed into octahedral coordination and the activity of catalyst is significantly reduced. The results show that the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions play the synergistic catalytic role with Cr ions. Interestingly, oxidation of cyclohexane is more inclined to produce cyclohexanol with uncalcined catalyst due to the presence of the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu ions; however, the appearance of surface lattice oxygen makes the reaction more conducive to cyclohexanone after calcination. After optimizing conditions, Cu-Cr oxide catalyst with the molar ratio 1:1 shows the highest activity, which obtains 62.2% yield and 92.4% selectivity for KA-oil using H2O2 as oxygen source.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of amorphous copper - chromium oxides catalysts for selective oxidation of cyclohexane
